content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												If you like a beautiful atmosphere, and a game with a great degree of challenge, reward for unbridled exploration and minimalist storytelling, stop reading and buy the game. It took me unlocking multi-dash, an extra health pack slot, an increased ammo clip and the ability to reflect projectiles with my sword, as well as the training accrued during the time it took exploring the world in order to gain these upgrades, to sufficiently prepare me with the skills to defeat the first boss I encountered.That's how much of a challenge he was. Which is why it was so glorious when his health bar hit zero, and my drifter did his victory dance. Those who would complain of difficult boss fights in games, well, this game has them. You'll need to be patient.Looking back, I could have probably killed him without the extra clip for my pistol, as well as the extra health pack. But I'm glad I gained these upgrades. Hyper Light Drifter is some kind of mix between the older Zelda titles, with a spattering of Dark Souls, and all the atmosphere of a game like Bastion. Once you get to the main hub, you can explore the world in four directions, with each direction ending in a boss fight. As you explore the world, you unlock upgrading chips which can be cashed in at shops in the main town. There are a number of upgrades affecting your sword, your guns, your movement, your health packs, and grenades. I'm about 23% through the game, based on what I've collected so far, and I can say at this point that it really doesn't matter what I picked up, except for maybe multi-dash/projectile reflection. Of the two boss fights I've done, they've seemed to be the most useful skills to have. I'd wager neither are necessary.The game is devoid of text, and there's no voice acting. Everything you discover, you do so through images that present events, and visuals that explain your purpose, etc. Talking to people consists of seeing a few images that make up their story, and in many cases, a symbol is added to your map. You're on your own to divine what everything means. Exploration of the world helps in this regard, as the atmosphere provides you context for the world you're in.Bonus points for that skeleton giant on the mountainside in the north. Seeing it in the background, and then actually encountering that area proper screamed Dark Souls. Each enemy has a differing amount of life, and a different moveset. If you're impatient, you'll quickly find your Navi-like sprite shouting at you to heal. Once you've run the gamut against a few of the same type of enemies, you'll no longer find yourself in this situation, instead dispatching groups of shuriken-throwing ninjas with untenable grace. I suggest picking up the sword-projectile deflection as soon as possible, as your ability to deflect can transform a pain-staking ambush into a slaughterhouse ballet. Bosses require a Dark Soulsesque amount of patience. Learning their moves, learning where you'll be safe, when you can attack using your different weapons, and again, maintaining safety, are your priorities. It can get frustrating, but I wouldn't call it twitch-style play. There's a certain amount of a grace period with regards to timing, at least as far as I've made it. You can set yourself up with quite a few potions with relative ease, allowing a greater grace for mistakes. Dying resets you to the closest checkpoint, which usually occur when you swap screens. Occasionally, you'll encouter ambush-style encounters where you can't escape until you clear the field, usually ending in a checkpoint. If you die in an area without hitting a checkpoint, all upgrades gained and enemies killed will respawn. Most enemies in an area do not respawn once dispatched.Health packs respawn, so you can properly prepare for boss fights, as well as exploring new areas.One of the few things I haven't yet mentioned is the ability to unlock "magenta triangles" for each of the areas you go to. I've yet to realize their significance in the context of lore. They're used to unlock specific doors in each of the 4 areas. Specifically, each area has its' own pieces, which you'll collect as you explore, allowing access for further exploration. Finally, there are a number of locked doors, labelled with a key symbol, which I've yet to unlock. Mysterious.At this point, I'm going to stop writing and continue playing. I have the urge to see another gorgeous vista. Plus, there're some water-submerged ruins that need picking through with a fine-tooth comb.Adieu.

Posted: December 24, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is one the few games which's awe and greatness I always struggle to describe, and I daresay I it's the grandest and most relatable thing have I ever played in my life. It draws a colorful and ominous world of non-verbal, environmental story-telling where even the tiniest prop plays part in a game-wide geometric supremacy. Same goes for cinematics, animation, music, level design, illustrations, sound and the UI art as well - everything fits perfectly together and I have yet to experience that degree of attention and detail in any other game I'm aware of.Gameplay-wise, you'll get an excellent mix of Zelda bits, Metroid-esque half-open world exploration and the combat strictness of something like Bloodborne or the Souls series. You can dash like a lightning, slice like a samurai and sport a bunch of guns for pretty much anything where the first two aren't enough. Almost every move you can learn, every gun you can find is gonna help you and play an important role in unriddling the secrets of the world. There are battles of both strategic and reactive quality, hidden rooms, half-invisible platform puzzles, satisfying bosses and a dozens of seemingly unrelated but yet delightfully mysterious collectables.And then, every so often, you'll find yourself soaked in this mix of flow, beauty, sorrow, delight, terror and and awe - all at the same time. It's a phenomenal experience to have, if not THE experience in your life as an appreciator of the superb. Moreover, it's the first game where I feel that it's more than a game, more than a game that is art. It's beyond art.Therefore, I wholeheartedly recommend playing Hyper Light Drifter. Especially if you have yet to play it.

												This game stirs my soul in evocative ways. It feels like an amalgam of my own past, escaping into 8-bit NES and titles like Blaster Master and Guardian Legend and Crystalis, although it's not a direct reference to any of those games... But it's like that, especially if you grew up playing 8- and 16-bit video games developed in Japan... Somehow mixed in all this is the DNA of visionary anime like Nausicaa and other fare.It feels like a conversation held in the chiptune pixelated language of an entire era and aesthetic. Something somber about it all, too, a bit gothic perhaps.  The game invites profound awe and introspection just one layer below the action with every sprite, background, and audio track.Hyper Light Drifter seems to come from the heart, and stands loudly proclaiming the artform of gaming lives on even as the world, wonder, and hope of our childhoods fade and are replaced with something more knowing, more appreciative of the fleeting good, and more weary of all in the world that erodes it.   It's especially poignant today; evocative of a cultural era that seems to be slipping through our fingers as the Japan of a generation or two ago that reached such stunning artistic heights in anime and digital media perhaps begins to fade.I'm still relatively early in the game, but would enthusiasticly recommend it to anyone who enjoys deep, quiet, beautiful exploration, tremendous atmosphere, exceptional music, and a bit of legitimately challenging twitch gameplay. :)

												Quite possibly my favorite game on steam. Everything about this game is great, from the music to the art style and overall gameplay. I love how it looks like a simple adventure indie game but at the same time I love how challenging and difficult it is behind all the prettiness that is this game. You don't necessarily need to collect everything to progress in the game, but if you're like me you want to 100% it and collect everything. And if the game isn't hard enough for you as it is you can try it on NG+ mode and make your life a whole lot more complicated.My only complaints about this game is on collecting items, it was a pain to collect all 186 gearbits and having no idea where to look for the ones I've missed. The game gives you hints as to there being secrets nearby I suggest you look for those once you start the game so you don't realize halfway like me and go through everything again and recheck every corner. Posted: August 15, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is one of the most beautiful and engaging indie titles I have played in recent years.It is quite an amazing feat because the game manages to achieve this almost without written text or direct exposition. It really and I mean really does not hold your hand when it comes to explaining the game mechanics or even the story. However, a beautiful world with a tragic story is there to explore and the journey is wholeheartedly worth it.Just take a look at the screenshots! You can tell that the art direction is fantastic and seeing it in motion coupled with an unforgettable music is just as amazing. The gameplay is reminiscent of the Souls games in a way that you have to slow down and react wisely during combat. A lot of people and reviewers noted that the game is needlessly hard sometimes and I strongly disagree. It is challenging but if you keep being patient and learn enemy patterns, you should overcome the hardest of the situations. (And this is coming from someone who has not played through a single Souls-like game.)I understand the controversy behind the game being locked to 30fps but it was not a deal-breaker for me. Personally, I would have preferred a 60fps lock overall, since technically you would have twice the time to react to enemy fire and also perform the dashing moves. The gameplay is fine really and anyone saying that it should be "60 fps or no purchase" should take off the chip from their shoulders.Overall, Hyper Light Drifter is an excellent example of how to tell a story and engage the players, sometimes in very moving ways, in its world just by using gameplay alone. I am simply left wanting more and I hope that the developer will soon add an expansion pack or anything that reveals more of this universe. It earns a wholehearted recommendation from me, even at full price.

content:
Posted: April 1
												This is a truly beautiful game. It amazing visuals, an amazing soundtrack, well-paced and engaging combat but also an alluring world that rewards exploration as well. The use of coloration and the game's unique stylized art themes, as well as its distinguishing lack of dialogue, give it a feel unlike any other, but at the same time evokes nostalgia in gamers who have played games such as A Link to the Past.While playing, the choices of where to explore and what to fight available to the player are abundant; while stuck in one area, players can fall back to a previous one and usually find something new, or practice their mechanical and/or combat skill to overcome the task at hand. Solid top-down melee mechanics and even ranged gameplay will enthrall gamers looking for action, but long sections of exploration or area progression will play to the sense of childlike wonder found in all who are ready to appreciate a game. Taking beauty and exploration that games like Zelda have done so well, and combining that with fast-paced and unique combat gives Hyper Light Drifter that nostalgic feel while also giving it a personality of its own.Perhaps the aspect of the game that makes players feel invested, beside the shear aesthetic beauty of the game, is that there are no words beyond the file select. The player interacts with NPCs through dialogue boxes containing pictures or brief demonstrations rather than actual dialogue. This may be intimidating at first, but the gameplay mechanics are intuitive enough for this to not be a problem, and it forces players to be more involved in discovering their world, successfully adding a sense of depth that is rarely seen.The only possible drawback to this game is that there simple is not enough of it; if players do not pressure themselves to explore the world to the fullest, they may find themselves progressing through the game a shallowly fast rate. However, anyone who is willing to appreciate this game to its fullest will take it slow, try to find every last secret and explore every last nook, and will not be dissapointed upon completion. Also, this game is highly replayable, as well has having an NG+ mode, so even if a player goes through it quickly, there is still more to get out of it.Ultimately, this is a game filled with breathtaking visuals, thrilling usage of colors, and a hair-raisingly beautiful soundtrack. By taking inspiration from successful elements of older games, it evokes a sense of nostalgia, but also adds its own personality through its original combat mechanics and atmosphere.10/10.

												Been wanting to play this game for a long time, so I was excited to finally explore its beautiful, cryptic world, but my expectations haven't been met unfortunately. The combat felt punishing and way too difficult, because it technically doesn't give you the finesse required to master the fights. Knowing it had four directions to go to, and discovering that each had a boss required to progress in the game, I was suprised to beat them all that fast. So the game was shorter than I thought, too.But once I closed the game to take a break I realized I had spent 4 hours and later finished the game with almost 9 hours played in one day and it felt like I played way less!The game grew on me and after a while my first impressions all have been eradicated - I begun to love the game more and more. The soundtrack is subtle and fits perfectly, ranging from lovely piano music to goregeous analogue, warm  synthesizers. The pixel art is beyond everything I have seen before, setting a new standard for what you can achieve with only pixels and a few colours. And the combat got easier after time once you know how to time your dashes and combos, making each encounter a well choreographed dance. Boss fights sometimes felt too easy, sometimes too hard, but overall it boils down to how well you can play - memorize attack patterns and behaviour, counter it with a dash and time your combos just right to make the most out of the small time windows where you can make your move.In a lot of ways this game reminded me of Titan Souls, although both are completely different. If you wonder if Hyper Light Drifter is something you would like, then give Titan Souls a shot. Should be easy to get since it was bundled a bunch of times.Review taken from my backlog profile.[backlog-deepness.rhcloud.com]

content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												The trees rustle in the distance. A faint summer breeze blushes against your cheek, then dies. Holding tight to your blade, you make your way though a magenta forest. The metalic taste of blood in your moulth reminds you that you don't have much time left.Hyper Light Drifter is a post apocalyptic tribute to classical Zelda games. You are a crimson traveler seeking a profaned crystal in hope of finding a cure for your illness. That is all I can tell about the story, not because I'm afraid of spoiling, but because it's fairly difficult to figure it out myself.Most of the story is told though the enviorment. Between the combat rooms, you travel though graveyards and laboratories, unraveling why the world came to what it is now. Impressive pixel art combined with an immersive ambience create a very strong atmosphere. So, even if you won't understand what you have played, you may still have a jolly fun experience.Now, the combat. The combat is generally quite simplistic and consists out of dashing, hacking away and occasionally using projectiles. Most of the challange comes from being forced to manage large groups of enemies. In a way, you can classify it as a bullet hell. The dash plays a key role in the game, as you are given a few moment of invincibility each time you use it. So, most of the time in the arena one will spend as a pink blur circuling around the room. The difficulty demands quick reaction times, up until you get the upgrades.Two extra medkits, a shotgun and the abulity that allows you to deflect bullets back at the enemy have a tendency to make most encounters anticlimactic.After completing the game, you will probably realize that you've missed about 60 percent of the content, since most of that content is quite well hidden. Everybody is expecting to find a spare upgrade part under the stair case, yet items that unlock new areas and game modes are so criptic to find, that there is no way the majority of players will uncover them without consulting a walkthough.My first playthough lasted about 10-12 hours and held my interest quite well. If you are a fan of dungeon crawlers set in a surreal apocalypse, mind giving this one a look. If you are hesitant, try picking this one up during the next Steam sale.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												----------------UPDATE-------------------I'm going to go back to playing easier games, like Dark Souls.------------------------------------------------My review will only be an initial one, as I haven't progressed much further through the game (so I won't comment on story quality yet).Firstly, if you're thinking of buying this game...when they say this game is recommended with a controller, they absolutely mean it. The keyboard controls are good, but the mouse aiming just doesn't quite work with the drifting mechanic, as often the direction you're indicating with the cursor will be drifted over, and so the direction of the NEXT drift is the opposite. So basically, joysticks all the way.The actual gameplay is excellent, and there's a clear emphasis on the pacing of attacks for a hack'n'slash title. You can't simply ghost an enemy and spam them with melee attacks, as the melee attacks aren't instantaneous in their duration and therefore leave a window for you to be damaged. The pistol/gun is also limited in its ammo, and you must refill it by killing enemies. It means you can't simply spam the gun, as it won't get you through a battle alone. Gameplay wise, the drift mechanic is pretty fun. Apart from traversing gaps in the terrain, it melds well into battling enemies as a dodge mechanic. It also assists in breaking up battles with the previous discussed melee and pistol/gun attacks, and the game seemingly encourages you to alternate between them, which is reinforced by the enemy's attack patterns. Level progression is also extremely Zelda-esque, a large open world with marked objectives and certain areas to continue story progression. So there's linear story progression but in an open-world, though I don't know if this will split into multiple story missions at this point (though it could). The possibility of some degree of non-linear story progression is only suggested to be possible as some story missions require you to travel to fetch various segments that combined will unlock the next story segment, so there's a degree of non-linearity in mission completion as is (the closest example I can think of like this is FEZ cube requirements when unlocking new sections). Additionally, the game also implements an auto-save system, so dying will result in respawning either at the beginning of the level (often occurs in dungeons), or nearby before a battle area. While autosave locations can often be annoying, or make a game overly easy, they have been well implemented in Hyper Light Drifter and strike a good balance, being useful without affecting difficulty. I say this because the game can be f*cking hard at times and no number of saves is going to help you.Where the game stands out is its audio and visuals, Disasterpeace delivering on another stellar soundtrack that really drives home the atmosphere of the environment drawn by the phenomenal pixel art. The illustrations are beautiful, and quite frankly, I've never seen pixel art better than this in a game. There are points in the game where you can just stop and look from piece to piece of the environment, noticing the detail put into each. I especially liked the detail put into the non-combat environments such the robots(?) frozen in time, covered with moss. It very much has Studio Ghibli's "Laputa: Castle in the Sky" appeal. It's hard to top this art direction, its been implemented perfectly.It's also worth noting the 30 fps lock. While it certainly isn't desirable, I found it to be barely noticeable even when playing with a mouse + keyboard (as framerates have an immediately noticeable impact on the responsiveness of a mouse), so again, a controller is the safe choice and the preferred option for this game. So far, so very, very good. I need to update this review when I can play it with a controller, but so far it's very much heading towards a "must own". Its hard to find games like this with such distinctive art direction and executed with such finesse, and actually giving back to the supporters instead of cr@pping on them with microtransactions etc.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												Absolutely one of the best games I've ever played. If you're still unsure about buying this cheap and complete classic, let me try and convince you:1). The visuals are stunning. I went in with lowish expectations because it was a pixel game, but god damn it's amazing what this game creates out of those small colourful squares. The graphic designers manage to create beautiful and remarkable landscapes with depth and awe that make you stop and appreciate the view for a bit. The sprites are all detailed and made with care, the animations and effects all combine in the heat of combat so nothing feels out of place. It all flows fantastically in a way that lets you know it was mastercrafted. 2). The sound design is just as good. The robotic sounding tunes manage to give off the feel the game is trying to convey, that of old busted technology scattered around, leaving mysteries behind for you to uncover. But those same robotic melodies are exactly that, melodic. They sound wonderful and fit beautifully, and the way they transition perfectly whenever you discover a great new sight or enemies appear and combat starts really keeps that aforementioned flow going.3). The gameplay is brilliant. It's all well and good for a game to look and sound good, but if it doesn't play well, it's a bad game. Well, luckily HLD hits the nail on the head in all departments. With a game that channels a Link To The Past inspired world with various different enviroments to explore with many unique enemies and landscapes, which change up the combat every time to keep it all fresh, you get a really good experience. The difficulty isn't low either. Many equiate it to Dark Souls, I would say I understand why but I wouldn't say so myself. The combat is a lot faster and more fluid, but in terms of how hard, I'd say its on par. 4). Lastly, the story. This game is very cryptic. It doesn't flat out tell you any story. It's a game with no voice acting at all, save for grunts made by NPCs, however you do get visual stories made up of several pictures when you talk to certain NPCs, which make up small stories of their experiences. This leaves you guessing, and perhaps you'll be looking up particular parts to understand what's going on. I'd say this is its only major downfall, as a beautiful single player RPG, I wish the story was a bit more comprehensible.That's about it. I really, really love this game, and I'm so sad it's as underappreciated as it is. This is a gem, a classic which will remain in my mind as one of the best games. Period. If you're looking for a inexpensive but fulfilling experience, you'd be doing yourself a disservice by not picking this up and playing it. Played my copy with an Xbox 360 controller and it was a very comfortable experience. A lot of people complain that it's locked at 30fps, but I can assure you it doesn't matter at all. The visuals make up for the not as silky-smooth experience, and I beg, please don't disregard this game because of something as trivial as an fps lock.

												Damn good fun... played several hours in the Kickstarter alpha alone, now, having begun to play the full release, they definitely did not disappoint. It's a mix of Bastion (post-apocalyptic-narrative/atmosphere/unique-stylish-aesthetic), Zelda (story-driven/adventure-exploration/mechanics/upgrades), and FEZ (atmospheric-music/sound-design=disasterpeace).Pros:-Very attractive and stylish pixel art, great sound design and atmospheric music (well designed, wholly coherent with complimentary components, from art & animation to sound effects & music.)-Mechanics have some depth and skill of use (drifting & swordplay, with upgrades).-World-building, Storytelling & Immersion (a variety of races, adding plenty to the world-building and atmosphere; vignette-based story-telling, relying on pictures and NPCs whose animations speak a thousand words; atmosphere reinforced through art, music & sound design, along with areas that have their own feel and design aesthetic).-Plenty to explore and many hidden areas (a charming home base, reminicient of Zelda A Link to the Past; variations on a theme, distinct and purposeful tilesets that have a story; cleverly hidden areas, requiring curiosity and persistence).Cons:-Performance hiccups - The game does suffer from slow-downs, as it was created using GameMaker and isnt the most optimized, sometimes making the game more difficult than it should be (eg: during combat, when trying to drift or attack, input does not register and frame rate drops like crazy, so you end up getting mauled to death when you would other wise have fended enemies off or even try to escape.) * If you are suffering from unusually low fps, it helps to make the game "Full Screen" if you have it set to "Windowed Max"-Forced, unnecessary revisiting - Some hidden areas require special items, from areas on opposite sides of the map - where this can push the player to revisit previously visited areas, it is downright needless and frustrating, as other guns that should have the same effect do not (eg: an area that requires the "Lazer Gun" to trigger a switch and not just the recently acquired "Zaliska"'s exploding bullets, which triggers other, much more hidden switches in the same locale). Upon a revisit to such an area, after defeating the boss and acquiring his special pistol, making sure that all the hidden areas were explored, one will only to find the recently acquired upgrade/pistol does not work. I understand if such instances are meant to give more 'gameplay', but it does not work in this game, due to the labyrinthian and complex map/area layout. It worked in Zelda and gave areas more use, but those areas were much more easily recalled and offered a simple, pleasant memory game.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is a top down pixelated hack & slash and shooter. The story start off with your character (a drifter) afflicted with a sickness that is killing them. They need to search the areas to discover answers for a cure. What interesting is that the whole story is told without any words being spoken or written. All "dialogue" is told using pictures. So I found myself talking to everyone and paying close attention to try to make sense of the story. Gameplay is fast pace. Initially you have a dash ability to dodge attacks and zip past enemies and sword to cut down enemies. The Drifter also carry around 2 health items that restore health (you can upgrade it to carry more). As the game progress you'll gain new guns and currency to get upgrades and new skills. The currency is rare to come by and require much exploration to amount enough to get enough for an upgrade. Now exploration is where this game struggle since the map is just confusing to look at, let alone use. You're better off just not using and walking against every wall of each area looking for a secret passage. Enemies are quite easy to beat, but can become overwhelming when force to take out multiple at once and different types. The Bosses are quite interesting and can give players a decent challenge. I've never found a boss that was just "unfair" in fighting them, but challenging enough to make me remember them. The traps in the dungeon and world are easy enough to get through and the puzzle are simple and easy to solve. The real draw of this game feel like the exploration because there are numerous locked doors that can require up to 10~12 keys to open. And when these keys are hidden throughout the area and the map is confusing to look at you will find yourself just wondering around hoping that your stumble upon a treasure.All in all the game is fun and short. The only real way to expand your playtime is to take your time to explore for all the keys and treasure. The combat feel tight and challenging but fair. The music is comfy to listen to as you play. A worthwhile indie game to play.

												One of the most aesthetically pleasing games I've ever played. Every single aspect of it, from the beautiful pixel art to the color palettes to the ambient music, contributes to the very immersive and enthralling atmosphere of the game. There's a simple joy in exploring this mysterious world, filled with anthropomorphic creatures that speak in pictures, long dead giants whose bodies have become part of the environment, and an intiguing mixture of fantasy and sci-fi elements.The story is kept vague and relies mostly on contextual clues from the surroundings, but that doesn't stop the game from having a cohesive if slightly cryptic narrative. The game encourages exploration and discovery, with many many secret rooms and items to uncover, and there's a genuine sense of accomplishment from finding little hidden pieces of the overall puzzle.As for the actual gameplay, it's challenging but fair. The combat relies a lot on good timing and reading your enemies, and you can unlock quite a few cool guns and upgrades. The dash move is especially useful, and makes the battles feel very fast paced and nerve-racking. And even though there are still some pretty difficult parts (made worse by the fact that checkpoints don't happen as often as I'd like) it never crosses the line into frustrating.All in all, a very memorable and enjoyable game!

Posted: July 22, 2016
												Don't play this game, it will ruin all other games for you by setting a new standard.I played this blind, didn't know anything about it other then what the trailer revealed. The gameplay is fast paced but slow at the same time. You can relax and enjoy the beautiful artwork or fight the difficult, skill-based monsters. A key feature that sets this game apart from other difficult, combat-orintated games, such as Dark Souls, is that the most challenging fights last less then a minute. The final boss shouldn't take you more then 10 minutes even if you die several times. Non-stop music, even when you die, keep you in the mode.There is no obvious story presented to you. The creator, so I've heard, takes much inspiration from the idea that you should not say any more then required for story telling. Other then a few tips in the beginning of how to play the game, the plot is up to you to decifer through vauge snapshots presented by some npcs. I've seen dozens of unique interpretations and I urge you not to look into any until you beat the game yourself. I guess you could say it shows a lot about you based on what you make the plot out to be, with your given protagonist and possible antagonists and mysterious surroundings.A major disappointment, however, was the New Game+ mode. Traditionally, a NG+ involves keeping all your gear from the previous game and restarting with more difficult enemies. The achievement you get from completeing this NG+ is correctly named, as you'd have to be a masochist to play through the entire game again with only 2 health (the standard damage of a boss's single hit) and all sword and drifting upgrades.26 hours played, only took 14 to beat the game and the other 12 searching for that last gearbit I still can't find... Frustrating for my fellow completionists, this game being one I gave up on that beautiful 100% mark, but worth every penny.

content:
Posted: January 9
												Hyper Light Drifter is an excellent A-RPG that reminded me a lot of A Link to the Past and other games from the 90s.In terms or artistic direction, the game looks and sounds amazing, everything fits together really well and contributes to a very pleasant experience. One of the most unique characteristic of this game is that everything is told with sound and pictures rather than words. It's a very nice form of storytelling I am not used to see and I found fit well with the rest of the game. It does leave a few things up to interpretation and makes it a little difficult to place names on people, enemies and locations, but made everything very interesting. I do think this helped, along with the sound, music and visuals, keeping an impressive level of consistency in terms of atmosphere and how everything felt. Everything feels desolate but unlike a lot of games, it feels intended and not just because of a lack of content.Gameplay is simple but definitely engaging and challenging. One of my mistakes was to assume this was more of a "Hack and Slash" type deal, although you quickly realize that spamming attacks and not being careful about your surroundings will only get you killed.Encounters always feel very precise, where you'll fight a certain number of enemies at once and are almost always better off trying to strategically take them out in order. Boss battles are also quite challenging and usually require memorizing attack patterns, although it's definitely not impossible to succeed on a first attempt.I have to say I was a bit misled at first and I feel like some people who don't enjoy the combat as much are not playing "correctly" (more carefuly and patiently instead of expecting a fast-paced action game). I've seen it compared to Dark Souls and I would agree.As with most A-RPGs, upgrades can be bought for the most parts and provide new tools to fight with, which are all interesting additions to your arsenal. Other will be found as you progress through the game. The amount of "backtracking" needed due to an item requirement is minimal.The game is heavily focused on exploration. The map is very similar to the one in ALTTP and will never show you exactly where you are, you will have to pay attention to landmarks and go from there when looking for something specific (or simply the way to your objective).Consequently, the game is almost entirely non-linear and can be completed in any order. The world is divided in 4 zones with different themeing (which is something I appreciate a lot), similar to Termina in Majora's mask, although less "Obvious" and more progressive. I did notice a difference in difficulty between areas but the order in which I completed them did not make me feel like an area was either too hard or too easy.I have to say exploration is definitely this game's strong point and finding secret locations definitely feels rewarding. However I do feel like the whole aspect where everything is visual made it very difficult for me to keep track of what I had done and what I had left to do. Although I did try to go everywhere and find everything I could find, I ended up finishing the game with a lot left to do, and a lot of "collectibles" missing. Because I usually tend to avoid reading much about games until I'm done with them, I have no clear idea of why I should go back and look for those.Because of this, I have completed the game and am curious to collect what I'm missing but have no incentive to do so. I do enjoy roaming around but while finding secrets along the way feels rewarding, deliberately looking for them for extensive periods of time feel rather tedious. I'm left with a game I feel I have not completed, but lack motivation to go back and complete everything. I do want to and will go back at some point. Right now however, I feel like it's too big of a commitment for a reward that might be non-existant. I have played games that got even better when I decided to put the extra time in, however (such as Anodyne) and will most likely update this review once I get around to it.If you love exploring and want to dedicate a lot of time to a single game, you probably won't feel this way. Other than this, it's an excellent game and definitely worth the price.

												Cool game. Fun mechanics. Lots of secrets. Insanely good spritework.I'll address some criticism that pop up on the forums:- 30fps. I enjoy 60fps as much as any other PC player, but it is seriously not a problem here. I never had problems with controlling the Drifter or getting anything done, aside from just playing poorly at a given moment.- Length. The game is of the perfect length. You'd think it should be like 40 hours long, but it'd just be padding. It doesn't overstay its welcome, instead focusing on quality over quantity. There's always NG+ if you really want to test your chops.- Story. The story is there, though it's not spelled out directly. There's a nice story analysis floating on the Internet, so once you finish, give it a read. It really blew my mind how crazy the story is.Overall, I really enjoyed it and may come back to it from time to time.

												Hyper Light Drifter combines Hack and Slash gameplay with a unique dashing ability and additional skills to create pretty fun fights - any boss fights are no exception to this.The visuals and soundtrack fit incredibly well, and further set the tone of the game, to a point where you don't even need dialogue or the like to follow through. You'll understand the gameplay basically by yourself (and have to, since there is only a very basic tutorial), and the story unfolds itself over time.Even if you may not be a fan of the core gameplay, another important part of the whole thing is exploration, since you have to do a lot of it to find everything there is in the game. It does get pretty tedious later on, but certainly isn't anything unfair. Most completely-out-of-sight secrets are just additional content, and not required to progress.This does require you to also be fine with backtracking, since it would be basically impossible to beat the game without returning to where you came from.Definitely recommended, alone for the atmosphere from the first few minutes of the game.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Been waiting with bated breath a couple of years for this game to drop. Every delay to the release has been greeted with a groan. Since yesterday's release I've only been able to play about 3 hours, but here's my experience of Hyper Light Drifter so far.For starters, there is no hand holding. No tutorial. I can count on one hand the number of times text has appeared on the screen during the actual game. Everything is learned by the player through well-crafted level design, first forcing you to learn a mechanic in order to proceed, then gradually training you on the different situational uses of that mechanic until it becomes second nature. This creates a satisfying sense that you have learned something organically rather than simply being told how to do it. Mechanics are simple and easy to pick up, but challenging to use very effectively. Best of all, combat feels just as tidy and stylish as it looks.The pixel art style is truly beautiful if you like that kind of thing. The levels are detailed and gorgeous with lots of little hidden pathways and small details. You're almost always rewarded for exploring and experimenting with combining your abilities with the level elements. The game leaves it entirely up to you where to go - there's no objective marker to follow. It starts you out at a crossroads and lets you dictate which direction you want to start exploring the world.Animations are simple enough to fit the art style, but intricate enough that they immediately communicate what they're trying to communicate. The cut-scenes are remeniscent of the classic *Another World* / *Flashback* games from the 90s.As much as the art is stylistically pretty, it is also extremely varied. There is very little in the way of copy-pasting when it comes to the level design. Every map feels individually crafted, every part of the world has a different feel. The ruins of the world you explore feel vast but deserted and creepy; caverns and other underground parts are suitably claustrophobic and atmospheric. It's amazing how such a simplistic art style is able to create such strong and varied atmospheres.The combat is challenging to the point of punishing, but incredibly satisfying due to the incredibly tight controls. If you die, it's almost always your fault, and there's almost always something you can take from it. Enemy AI is varied but surprisingly smart - enemies will dodge and flank you, and you have to be precise with your movements. Mashing the sword button will certainly not automatically win engagements.You will die a lot. If you don't like punishing games and would rather romp through a story without being challenged at all, this really is not a game for you. At all.The checkpoint and fast travel systems are very well implemented. You barely notice they're there.The music and overall sound design is incredible and one of my favourite features of the game so far. If you've been watching any of the trailers or know of Disasterpeace's work then you know what to expect - dark, atmospheric chiptune-esque beats that ebb and flow with the on-screen action. SFX are crisp and fit the game's style perfectly.Overall, I'm very much enjoying my experience so far with Hyper Light Drifter, and can't wait for work to be over so I can dive back in to the world.My only criticism so far is minor: the game seems to be capped at 30fps. Nowadays it feels less smooth and satisfying than the 60fps I'm used to in most games, but particularly for a game with this kind of old-school pixel art style. While it hasn't hampered my enjoyment of the game itself it still seemed a strange limitation.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												This review was published as of my first hour of gameplay.This game is legendary. I have never in my life, AAA games included ever been so absolutley stunned by the graphics of a game. This is one of if not the most atmospheric game I have ever played, the soundtrack, SFX and visuals come together to make one of the most perfectly beautiful things i have ever seen. Even if the gameplay was terrible i'd recommend this game just for the experience. However, i don't have to recommend it on the presentation alone because the gameplay is FANTASTIC. The three combat mechanics I've seen so far are all wonderful, and blend together perfectly. As of right now i have a gun, a sword, and a dash. The gun is filled via successful hits on enemies/breaking random containers in the world, which makes it fit well in combat as it gives you a powerful and satisfying ranged option whilst never invalidating the sword. The dash flows well in both explorative gameplay and combat, and is exactly the kind of ability that fits the weapons you're given in this game. This game is also difficult, with healing items seeming uncommon and enemies dealing large portions of your health in a single hit. This being said, the game never feels impossible or unfair. This will be, no doubt, my Indie GOTY 2016. I only have two issues with it so far, and both are very minor. The first issue is that you can easily click outside the fullscreen window, and because i have a second monitor i end up going too far right with my mouse sometimes, causing the game to tab out. However, after an hour of gameplay i've taught myself to just not do that and it's almost a nonissue at this point. [[THIS WAS PATCHED DAY 1]The second issue i have with this game is that the death/respawing animation seems to drag on, and (possibly because i'm trash) i die a lot in this game, and sitting there waiting really breaks this game's wonderful combat flow.] However, these two small issues overall don't detract from the gaming magnum opus that is: Hyper Light Drifter. TL;DR versionGame is really pretty, the combat flows like a river, and issues are minimal.9/10

TLDR: You're not going to master this game, or even be good at it on the first play through. Why? Because you don't know what anything is or what it does and the game doesn't tell you until it's too late. Buy it. It's pretty.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is a fun 2D action combat game which focuses on exploration and intense combat. You play as a character with access to a sword, various guns, and a dash. Combat consists of fighting off swarms of enemies with different attack patterns that require learning. With only five points of health and limited full heal kits, surviving takes limiting the hits you let yourself take and the timing/usage of your scarce healing.The actual game world is a huge overworld interspersed with dungeons, secret locations, and beautiful, screenshot worthy resting places free of the combat's franticness, that just deserve a moment to take in. The world can be easily navigated physically through dashing to cross the many chasms and visually through the understandable map that shows both the surface and underground layers. There is a central city where you can upgrade your gear with the game world's currency. Surrounding this are the four major zones, which for the most part can be tackled in any order. Each zone has a different theme and different enemies to master. Each zone also has a major boss fight. Some may take a few deaths to fully master the pattern, but they are all very fair despite the challenge. The game is a blast to play. Combat becomes a rhythmic mixup of swordplay and gun sniping as you work down large groups of enemies. There are a variety of collectables hidden throughout the game in many of the secret locations (hidden walls, out of the way platforms, etc). I've read complaints that wall hugging is needed at many points to find collectables, but the game does a very good job of subtly showing the locations of hidden places, either by having well placed visual indicators or by showing a peek at the location when you stand in certain spots. You know an area that you can't immediately access is there, so you'll be compelled to find the route to it. The game takes about ten hours or less to complete the main story based on my first playthrough of it. Yet, there is still more to do as I've yet to collect everything or start the game's new game plus mode.I definitely recommend this game. I've had a few bugs and a few crashes, but the developers have been working since launch with updates to smooth them out. The game has a great feel. Combat is fair, but it's still difficult and requires learning. Nothing beats the feeling of beating a particularly hard mob, and being rewarded with the silent protagonist mirroring your feeling of triumph by victoriously throwing his sword into the ground. It's great, it's fun, and it doesn't require a whole lot of time if you just want to beat it and move on. Go with this game if you like the genre and art of a 2D pixel game with challenging combat, and more importantly a lot of heart.

content:
Posted: March 2
												After about 50 hours I think its time to review this game. This is my favorite game of 2016. It has no ambitious story, no hidden meaning, no crazy twist ending. Its a video game. This game does not "extend the medium" or "Deliver a new layer of immersion" its just a damn good game, and its been a while since I have played one of those. The combat is fast and fluid, like Bloodborne it feels more like a dance than combat. The firearms and powers blend seamlessly with the rest of the sword slashes and dashing. The bosses are a cut above amazing. They are challenging but always fair (except the Northern boss on NG+). They all have diverse designs and just as diverse ways of fighting. The story is loose and mostly absent, but I felt this ominous feeling that something horrible had happened and it really created an atmosphere that I have never experienced in any other game. I don't like to give number ratings for things, I tend to recommend something on a should you or should you not play. But I think that I would be comfortable giving this game a 10/10 if I were asked to rate it on a scale. I have problems with it (the northern boss on NG+) but none of them would keep me from even considering to tell you not to buy this game.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter, in a lot of ways is simply a action-platformer.Although many say it’s a indie Darksouls game, it more in-line with Devil May Cry or Bastion type game, as there is no punishment for dying. The game's combat and special moves resemble Devil May Cry with gun-sword combat, deflecting projectiles, perfect-timed swings and platforming, the game also borrows a lot from Bastion’s top down game mechanics.The pacing and level design of the game resemble more closely to a Zelda type game, with freedom to go to three available directions; East, North and West. In my playthrough I started with the North. At the North I learn hints of the backstory and lore through its environments and pictograms-dialog from engaging with the NPC. Talking about environments, there are secrets, hidden switches and hidden rooms everywhere, I once also found a hidden switch that lead to a hidden room with more hidden rooms. Which leads me to say “Way too much wall hugging” thankfully there are community guides if you so wish to use them.In conclusion, Hyper Light Drifter is blend of multiple great games, but does not simply just copy, but make it their own unique design and style. A great recommendation for all!

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												What an amazing game. You're thrust into the world with minimal information and only a vague idea of your goal and how to get there. No hand holding, no in-depth exposition, just a mysterious 3 minute opening cutscene and that's it. For the most part there's no decipherable text or speech anywhere at any point, as the game relies on subtle auditory, musical, and visual cues to tell its story. And in case you couldn't tell from the trailers, it's stunningly beautiful throughout. The world has been put together with such care and detail that at times I was fighting my enemies just so I could more easily appreciate the settings. There's also small details that make the game seem that much more fully fleshed out; for instance, after a small period of inactivity your character will sit down on the ground. As alluded to before there's a completely unique alphabet in the game that can and has been decrypted.But yes, this game is HARD. I'll admit I'm not the most skilled at games. I tend to play games on easy-medium difficulty settings just so I can keep up. But even I can tell this game is very difficult, and there is no adjustment for the difficulty. Enemies move nearly as quickly as you do and often times deal more damage than you do, and health kits are usually either in short supply or very well hidden. The bosses are even faster and can often kill you if you're not careful in a matter of seconds. It's a difficult game to get right, but when you finally manage to nail down a room full of enemies or one of the bosses, it's super satisfying, and you feel like some kind of video gaming wizard.My only complaints were with the weapon upgrade system, which consists solely of being able to carry more ammo, as well as the in-game map, which only shows you very generally where you are and can be difficult to read at times.Overall I absolutely loved this game, despite dying constantly. The setting is the best example of modern pixel art I can think of, the story is engaging and mysterious at the same time, and the gameplay is satisfying.

All-in-all, fantastic game.

content:

												This game is simply wonderful. I'm a sucker for pixel-art, and this game delivers with a diverse colour palette, snappy animation, and downright beautiful world design.The combat really drives the experience; it's difficult without feeling unfair, but it can be punishing of mistakes -- it's similar to a Dark Souls title in that regard, specifically Bloodborne for the fast-paced, dash-heavy combat.It's also similar to a Soulsborne title in that the story isn't just laid out in front of you -- there's never a moment where the game takes you by the hand and says "Okay son, here's the story." I love devs that are brave enough to let their worlds and their stories stand on their own without worrying that someone might not "get" what's going on; I much prefer to have a mysterious story that I might not catch all of, revealed to me in snippets or by clues in the environments themselves.In short, you should buy this game. It's great.

												A game that definitely surprised me. Mainly taking influence from Zelda (along with its own new ideas to make it stand out) and some influence from Dark Souls.Its core combat is similar to Zelda but is more about timing like in dark souls (getting hit does tons of damage too) with a fast paced hack n slash feel to it. The hub itself also have shops with upgrades, mini games to play and secrets of its own. Really like how the game throws you into the world and expects you to find your own way. The music is great and very moody. Really atmospheric stuff. The visuals and animations are top notch for a 2D game, especially one made in game maker. Its also been polished over time and now can run at stable 60 FPS. However it can still use some more polish in other areas.I dont have many complaints but if I were to nitpick the coop is unfortunately non existent. Fantastic game: 9/10Cant wait for a sequel!

												Music: Awesome. Matches the world perfectly.Gameplay: Awesome. Combat has nice flow and is the right ammount of difficult (not very hard actually).Graphics: Awesome. Great use of colours and lights/shaders.Story: Now, here's the thing. I'm going to say "Awesome" but this is very subjective. There's many places where you can look at the environment and relate it with other places & imagery to understand what happened in this world, AKA environmental storytelling, but there's no thing such as story being told to your face, with letters. Actually, there is some "text" with "story", but it's hard to find & interpret (others have done it all already though), and that's about it.Just a little summary of its story, you know. In case you are the "tell it to my face" kind.Bonus:Controls: I'm usually a KB+M fan but for this one I recommend playing with a controller.Mouse pros: Aim in any direction easily on-the-fly with your mouse.Mouse cons: You dash towards the mouse. Hard to dash backwards. Can be fixed by switching dash direction to match your movement direction (WASD) but that limits it to 8 directions.Controller pros: Really easy to dash in any direction (not limited to 8).Controller cons: Hard to aim on-the-fly. There is a dedicated button for aiming without moving but you are then (obviously) forced to stand still as it uses the movement stick. In my case I didn't really need to be precise while aiming (in combat), but rather dashing.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is a breath taking game with strategic hack and slash and a progression style similar to older Legend of Zelda games. I've glanced at other peoples reviews, and in general what they say still holds up:-The gameplay itself is challenging, and if you learn to efficiently dispatch your foes you'll fine there'll be an abundance of health packs.-Secrets, secrets everywhere. Sniff the walls all day long but honestly I found that to be enjoyable - finding new areas, extra items and tid bits was something I've always liked to do in games anyway (although this game has certainly outdone itself in number of hidden stuff behind seemingly impassible walls - even the secrets have secrets. No, really-).-Aside from the Monument text that you have to decode (Purely extra stuff - just reveals more about the story, even if the translations themselves are vague) and the text in the game telling you what button does what everything is told to you via pictures and images. Even important story details and objectives. No seriously - I didn't fully realize what that map was in the Guardian Drifters house until I started pulling up the things in the East area, and by then I'd missed two of the gem things needed to open the Boss door. I got frustrated, wasn't sure how to read the map and didn't want to back track (the thing I loathe the most in games) so I looked up someone doing a run through of the East area to see what I missed. It was only then and after I connected the symbols the Guardian had showed me on the map did I realize what I needed to find and why. After that I was fine but it was still very unclear to me at first and disconnected me a bit from the game world itself. I guess it was also a little disapointing to find out that getting four of those gem triangle things instead of three (the min you need for the Boss of each region) didn't really give you anything new except for a quick rehash of the opening and illness induced nightmares. I don't BELIEVE getting four in each region did anything to affect my end of the game stuff (it certainly didn't seem like it) but there's no real benefit from getting four of them, so any hopes of extra cutscenes, pictures, or interactions that told you something more (or at least something more obvious) were trashed. Bummer.-Despite that previous combo paragraph, the scenary always drew you back into the mysticality of the enviornment, as long as you were focused on the game and not preoccupied with anything else (stressed? not invested? Hard to take in the story).And to continue off of that note despite me, personally, still liking the game comes one thing that disapointed me more then anything else - lack of concrete... I don't know the word for it but it needs more key points story wise. Letting you know right now if you don't like/care about stories in games this one is still great - gameplays fantastic bosses are fun to fight. Story is still great regardless.. but..It's super vague. I mean, so vague to the point where you gotta start making stuff up for even important plot points like the titans in the opening cutscene and the Drifter themselves. Other then what you see blatantly on the screen (and what you can translate outside the game from the Monuments) everything else is a theory. The Dog? Anything you can guess about it or it's origin - theory. Titans? Even calling it a Titan is a theory - could have been Giants, or some other species created by someone else - or not. The game is very open ended in it's ENTIRE story (they give you pieces and you basically build it) and despite it's visual approach the Drifter doesn't react to any of it. You really only get bits of the Drifters personality from how they're animated. Other then that and the cutscenes his personality is very interpretive and... I dunno about you but with games like this I'd like a few more story keys or personal ties from character interactions to draw me into the world a bit more. After that intense opening cutscene, I was kinda sad to find there wasn't much more then that (even the ending one was lacking but at that point I was taking what I could get).Grant it I haven't found every secret in the game YET but I've been looking around and if you've been in the fandom business for atleast a cycle or two you'd know spoilers are usually one of the first things you see when you're indulging in  lore and fanart and I have yet to be spoiled by anything I might have missed. Haven't heard a lick about it so I just assume it doesn't exist until I find it.If you wanted a story told TO you this games really bad at that. You really gotta put pieces together to form any sort of picture about the world in your mind and by doing that you get drawn into the world as the Drifter. For all we know they know about as little as you do, so your curiosity, your lack of information is their lack of information.If you wanted to dive yourself into a world and examine the pieces this games good at that.To get out of the story perspective, though...Gameplay? Amazing. Not too challenging and fun to engage in.Visuals? Astounding. There will definitely be sections you'd want to screen cap or stare at for a few minutes at a time - sometimes longer.Music? Atmospheric - most of it is relaxing or dreadful (boss fights). It's very unique to the game itself.Story? I still like it but... it's frustrating to me all the same. I wish there was more key points told to you, more definites, more to work off of besides all these loose puzzle pieces that don't easily match up - but the Monuments are the same way, only more obvious..Maybe the whole stories there like how we can translate the Monuments, I have no idea. Probably. The pictures are puzzle pieces in this race to see what the definite story is - but then they'd all still be theories. I could run this in a rat race all day, but really this game is great. Regardless of whether or not it's on sale I'd recommend it. If you're still unsure, wait until it's on sale. Still a great game, still a good story even if I think it's a bit too open ended; I still liked it.And yeah I realize this is just me kinda being disappointed with lack of concrete story points but I figured I'd add my two cents in where no one else seems to be poking at it. Or at least not as prominently. I might edit this later when I replay it.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												I'm glad, I blindly backed every Kickstarter project I thought looked cool a few years ago when I had some money left over and then totally forgot about it afterwards. Hyper Light Drifter is such a game and boy, was the surprise nice, when I suddenly received this Steam key out of the seeming blue.Hyper Light Drifter is a wonderful experience that combines calm exploration with beautiful visuals and a soothing soundtrack with punishingly hard fights. It's never too hard, however; the game just lets you progress naturally, in a Dark Souls-esque way. (I've never played much of any Dark Souls title, sadly, but after this game, I strongly want to, again.)The game rewards curiosity and persistence just as much as it punishes greed and rush, you want to carefully explore the world to not die and lose your progress since the last save. The game isn't perfect tho; while hard, sometimes the checkpoints are mostly set between map transitions, sometimes in such a way that you can easily exploit their placement. Especially when you don't want to repeat the arbitrary collecting action after eery respawn, you just collect after respawning, leave the area, enter again and then you don't have to do so again - that feels a bit counter intuitive to me.Otherweise I can't think of many other negative aspects in HLD. A few things, that positively stuck out, in my opinion, were the almost total lack of text in the game. Except for the HUD and very brief control explanations, all written and spoken language is abandoned, so the game focuses on visual storytelling instead. Also, Disasterpiece did a great job at the music composition once again and its implementation is superb. The music and sound design do their part on the non verbal storytelling and it shows.I don't have much more to say right now, except that this game deserves more attention. I am sure more people would (and hopefully will) enjoy this masterpiece but I kind of expect it to become an insider tip.Highly recommended.

Posted: April 15
												A game that definitely surprised me. Mainly taking influence from Zelda (along with its own new ideas to make it stand out) and some influence from Dark Souls.Its core combat is similar to Zelda but is more about timing like in dark souls (getting hit does tons of damage too) with a fast paced hack n slash feel to it. The combat is a blast and quite challenging. Its a hard game but you will begin to understand its rythms and the tutorial is good. Exploring the dungeons are great as the level design is phenomenal with many secrets hidden within them. Exploration in HLD is just amazing hands down. Each area has a unique look n feel and unique enemies to them. The game gives you a hub area and you are free to explore any of the four zones whenever you want. The hub itself also have shops with upgrades, mini games to play and secrets of its own. Really like how the game throws you into the world and expects you to find your own way. The music is great and very moody. Really atmospheric stuff. The visuals and animations are top notch for a 2D game, especially one made in game maker. Its also been polished over time and now can run at stable 60 FPS. However it can still use some more polish in other areas.I dont have many complaints but if I were to nitpick the coop is unfortunately non existent. Fantastic game: 9/10Cant wait for a sequel!

												I completely agree with all the positive things that are being said about the game, but there's one thing that I haven't seen people discuss: Post-release updates. Hyper Light Drifter has been recieving constant patches, bug fixes, and even free additions into the game. Not only did they add support for 60 FPS, they made it possible to switch between it and 30. It's little additions like this that make Heart Machine such and excellent company. They even added an easy mode for people who wanted it. This is, in my opinion, the model of a good Indie team. Post game patches that improve an already masterful game, and making sure everyone can enjoy it without ruining what they already had. Buy this game, if only to support the people who created it.

												Hyper Light Drifter is a cybernetic ninja roaming the ruins of a once great society. He has a bad case of the blood coughies and he frequently hallucinates/remembers a cyber genie killing him. A deified dog appears to be watching his every move and dead titan carcasses are everywhere. Between all the secret areas, combat scenarios, enemy types, upgrades, unique boss fights, interleaved level design, tight controls, there's also all the gorgeous pixel art and ambient sound design. Compares well to Cave Story, Dark Souls, and Fez.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												I'm glad, I blindly backed every Kickstarter project I thought looked cool a few years ago when I had some money left over and then totally forgot about it afterwards. Hyper Light Drifter is such a game and boy, was the surprise nice, when I suddenly received this Steam key out of the seeming blue.Hyper Light Drifter is a wonderful experience that combines calm exploration with beautiful visuals and a soothing soundtrack with punishingly hard fights. It's never too hard, however; the game just lets you progress naturally, in a Dark Souls-esque way. (I've never played much of any Dark Souls title, sadly, but after this game, I strongly want to, again.)The game rewards curiosity and persistence just as much as it punishes greed and rush, you want to carefully explore the world to not die and lose your progress since the last save. The game isn't perfect tho; while hard, sometimes the checkpoints are mostly set between map transitions, sometimes in such a way that you can easily exploit their placement. Especially when you don't want to repeat the arbitrary collecting action after eery respawn, you just collect after respawning, leave the area, enter again and then you don't have to do so again - that feels a bit counter intuitive to me.Otherweise I can't think of many other negative aspects in HLD. A few things, that positively stuck out, in my opinion, were the almost total lack of text in the game. Except for the HUD and very brief control explanations, all written and spoken language is abandoned, so the game focuses on visual storytelling instead. Also, Disasterpiece did a great job at the music composition once again and its implementation is superb. The music and sound design do their part on the non verbal storytelling and it shows.I don't have much more to say right now, except that this game deserves more attention. I am sure more people would (and hopefully will) enjoy this masterpiece but I kind of expect it to become an insider tip.Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												A friendly warning if you have come across this game, and want to buy it on the screenshots alone. Hyper Light Drifter is HARD. Not impossible, not completely hardcore insane, not even your run-of-the-mill roguelike or bullet hell shooter hard, but it will definitely challenge casual gamers who are looking for a fun and relaxed experience.And what an experience it is. Not quite metroidvania, not quite soulslike, yet drawing from both, this game will see you exploring environments rendered in lovely pixel art, occasionally fighting monsters and doing a little platforming before fighting a boss at the end of each area. Right from the beginning, the game lets you go in three different directions, letting you choose what path to take and which bosses to take on first.Both combat and platforming rely heavily on your dash ability, which you have from the start. Many enemies have dash attacks as well, so combat often becomes a wonderful dance of timed dodges and quick counter-attacks, and the first time you finish a large encounter and your enemies lie in pieces at your feet, you will feel like a god!Overall, I'd recommend this game on what little I have played. But like I mentioned earlier, this game is not for everyone. I'd just like lastly elaborate on the difficulty so you know exactly what you are getting into:- Bosses are VERY aggressive and deal a large amount of damage, and will change their attack patterns over the course of the fight. You will be overrun by adds, and stunlocked while attempting to heal. Your health bar is pitifully small, so sometimes you could go from full health to 0 HP in under a second. You will die. A lot. There are abilities you can buy to complement your arsenal and skills, but apart from the ability to carry an additional medkit, I have yet to find anything that would actually really help you stay alive if you aren't that confident in your abilities in the first place.- Apart from the bosses, there are a number of occasions when you are locked in a room with a large number of enemies. If you die, you restart at a previous checkpoint, but with the same amount of HP and medkits you had going in, so if you were low on supplies to start with, you might have a lot of trouble. Remember that you can always teleport out to the hub, and go farm some medkits and try again.- In the style of many oldschool 2d games, secrets in this game sometimes involve a lot of just running up against every wall in the hopes of finding a hidden passage. Sometimes they are well telegraphed, with clues in the environment, but other times it felt like dumb luck. At times this can get quite frustrating.All in all, it's a great game. It's just not for everyone. If you like this type of game however, you would do well to check it out.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												This game. Wow. I went into this game completely blind, being drawn in by what looked to be great visuals backed by a fantastic soundtrack all supporting tight, satisfying fight mechanics, and it delivered.Don't play it for the story, necessarily. Just know you're in an apocalyptic world battling warrior raccoons, fanatic bird zealots, cannabalistic frogs, and artificial life experiments gone wrong, all while being haunted by a mysterious shadow. If that doesn't draw you in already, I don't know what else to say.The soundtrack and visuals are so well-done and fitting for every moment in the game. If you press the button (or key) for down, your character will actually sit down and chill. This game actually made me want to stop what I was doing and just sit once or twice, just to soak in a particularly fantastic sight, accompanied with great musical ambience.Now, this game is not for everyone. If you prefer games with more focus and direction, and maybe some more clearly explained plot, then look somewhere else. In addition, the combat rewards skill and severly punishes button mashing, so if you want hand-holding, you won't get it here.  But if you're looking for a game with excellent combat mechanics and an adventure that will take you from the tops of the mountain shrines to the bowels of underground factories, with myriads of enemies to take down swiftly and skillfully, this is for you.Let me be a bit more specific concerning the combat. You will die a lot figuring them out, but once you get it, you will be dashing all over the various arenas of monsters, slaying them with impunity. Reflecting projectiles and unleashing powerful charge attacks are just a few of the abilities at your disposal once you unlock them with the currency you'll find hidden throughout the map.Speaking of which, if I had a gripe about the game, its the map. I would prefer to be able to know where I've already been, and whether I've found all the items in that area or not so that I do not have to waste too much time backtracking.Now, they recently made it 60 fps, which was not absolutely necessary, but definitely made the game less frustrating, as every frame counts. They also included a boss rush mode, which is one of my favorite parts of the game. Oh, and it has co-op!All in all, this is one of my favorite games I've played this year so far. It's so vibrant, fun, and challenging. If you'd like to play a game that encourages exploration and a mastery of the combat mechanics in order to fully appreciate it, and experience a world with mysterious but intriguing history, get this game. You won't regret it.Dat north bird boss fight tho... I died like 50 times. Tread carefully.

I didn't get a lot of the achievements I was supposed to get during my first playthrough.

Secrets are (almost) always hidden in reasonable spots that you can find if you just pay enough attention.+Moveset is advanced and difficult to master, but also rewarding to use.-Wonky collision, accidentally clipped at points and ledges aren't always friendly.-Crashes frequently on Yosemite (10.10.5). It never got in my way too much since it usually happens around screen transition (so you usually autosave before the crash). This might also have something to do with my controller, haven't tested or anything.-Some sections were more frustrating than enjoyable because of bad placement (or no placement) of save spots.-Some achievements are broken. I didn't get a lot of the achievements I was supposed to get during my first playthrough.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter can be best described as a mixture between The Legend of Zelda and Dark Souls. The game is difficult, but fair and, like Dark Souls, the story is never handed to you and if you want to know whats going on youre going to have to explore a lot. The game also has a total of four dungeons, that can be beaten in any order, well except for the South dungeon. The combat animations are fluid and the mixture of Sword and gun combat is quite satisfying. It is also very dash heavy as it is the only way to avoid enemy attacks. All upgrades can be purchased in any order from the start of the game, but the currency is somewhat scarce and hard to find so pick your upgrades wisely. The games lenghth is around 8 to 10 on your first play through and there are new game plus options for those completionists out there. The only cons I could think of is that there are no words said or spoken by any characters in the game, thus leaving you confused as to what the heck is going on, but if you like that type of story then more power to you. There are also occasional bugs were the a cutscene might trigger too early. The game is also locked at 30 fps so if you cant stand that beware.I would highly recommend this game to all fans of Zelda's combat and Dark Soul's style of story telling, and despite it's minor flaws I believe the art style and combat system are well worth the price of admission.
