content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Easily one of the best games to come out this year, and the best game I've played this year. My jaw dropped when i saw the opening animation. Without anything approaching a word being uttered, just the sublime soundtrack and astounding pixel art, I felt more of a connection to the Drifter than to many other characters in books, films and videogames. And the game just kept delivering.For anyone that complains about the story being too vague, I feel that this simply isn't the case. HLD does a good job at world-building, and the little animations and 'text-boxes' that you see when interacting with NPCs highlight how the world is calm in the city-hub, but outside it there are all sorts of dangers. All the gameplay elements are on-point. Combat feels satisfying and rewarding, suitably Souls-esque with Zelda thrown in for good measure.Admittedly, I did get stuck at some points in the game, but a quick glance at a walkthrough will set you on the right path.All in all, Hyper Light Drifter is a thought-provoking, satisfying, mesmerising powerhouse of a game that I cannot recommend highly enough.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is an excellent game. 9/10. Would recommend. Read below for further details.PROS - Atmosphere: From the very beginning you are sucked into this world. The music and art design blend together wonderfully creating a drive to explore your surroundings.- Combat: Battles require precision over mashing. The controls felt tight and once you understand what enemies are capable of battles become a dance. You'll battle melee and ranged foes, sometimes at once. Dispaching a room of enemies without taking damage is very satisfying. - Level design: There are four distinct areas to explore in HLD. There is a minimap but I rarely had to use it. The levels have enough branching paths but not too many that you get lost often. There are NUMEROUS hidden nooks and crannies to find. There are some environmental tells but the visuals are so cohesive that the player really has to look and explore to find extra goodies. This is where the dash movement mechanic really shines as you'll constantly find yourself dsahing across gaps to small ledges in search of secrets. The developers really did setup the environment to syngergize with the core movement mechanic of dashing.- Boss Battles: While many people feel the battles are too hard, I though the difficulty was well tuned. All of the bosses have a unique visual design and require different strategies to beat. There was never a boss I had to replay more than seven times (including the final boss). You revive right outside the boss room and a recent patch sped up the player death animation so restarting was not frustratingand after every death. The battles are tense and require constant focus but that makes victory that much more satisfying. I was able to beat the entire game without buying any healing upgrades so with healing fully upgraded I feel many players can complete the game if they learn the patterns and stay determined.CONS- Upgrade System: Melee attacks, movement abilities, and the secondary gun can be upgraded along with a few other things. In keeping with zero dialogue or explanatory text the upgrades merely show a quick clip of what they are. This does leave some ambiguity in what new abilities do. Also, as all upgrades can be purchased from the beginning, choosing an upgrade is simply guesswork. All of the abilities are useful (to an extent) but the currency to purchase them has to be found through exploration so new upgrades can only be purchased so quickly. Buy one you won't need for some time and you're out currency and the gameplay doesnt change. I did a decent amount of additional exploration and did not find enough currency to upgrade everything. Not a problem to me personally but then I was happy with what I chose to upgrade.- Autosave System: I understand why the game has auto-save. It allows the devs to provide difficult sections of the game. The game saves so often I don't think I was never bothered but life does happen so be aware you can't stop playing whenever you want (unless you don't mind replaying a section).- Length: I was only lost once that I can recall and I didn't waste much time dashing around (for a certain achievement) and I beat the game in six hours. I was hoping for an 8-10 hour experience. There is a new game plus and I didn't get all the collectables but for what I'm calling the main game, it was a tad short.Overall Impression- Hyper Light Drifter was worth the 18 USD (sale price). Some of the best boss fights I've played. Great combat. The story presentation being purely visual challenged me to think about the world and what the Drifter's purpose was. Is the game difficult? At times, but you are given all the tools to overcome. Like many of the best indie games, Hyper Light Drifter provides a unique and focused experience you will not get anywhere else.

content:
Posted: April 6
												Where to even begin....I rarely do product reviews...especially for things I like or cherish because I typically feel like whatever I may type cannot give a just picture of what I experienced. There are parts of this game when the music, visuals and mechanics sync up and manage to pull literally every emotion in the spectrum from you. I have played indie games before, but for me personally, this was my "Fez" moment; my 'Bastion" (and I played/own Bastion!!); the kickstarter I wish I had backed. It had just the right thematic/mechanical elements to keep me hooked deep in. I have read this in reviews below and I completely echo the sentiment: if Zelda: Links Awakening and Darksouls had a sweet, sweet love child while listening to the Tron soundtrack; this be it.Above is a mish mash; an amalgalmation of my euphoria when playing this game. More of that to come. The boss fights are challenging and rewards you (the player) for finding the right combination of moves by getting to witness  the drifter dance to victory; not unlike perfect choreography. The landscape/environs are brooding, surreal and meaty; which is incredible considering the Isometric perspective of the game. The music. The F********* MUSIC!!!! I am literally going to pick up Fez because of the music in this game alone. I found myself purposely dash chaining through sections (especially in the eastern water section) to hear the unique backing tracks SEEMLESSLY blend into eachother. Intro music is easily one of my top ten intro songs. It is a feature light game with single player and co op campaign options ( hooray local coop; I hate online coop and like eating pizza and crushing dirks with my friends IN PERSON) and a new game plus option. Thats it and it makes the game a much more focused experience because of  this fact.I waited for the game to go on sale to pick it up and after my positive experience with Bastion's soundtrack edition,decided to spring for the soundtrack edition for this as well. Easily one of the best bargains/purchases i have ever made. I am completely invested in the indie craze now!!!Brass Tacks:Sound: 10/10Controls: 10/10Story: ?/10*My only small nitpick (F****** microscopic): I wish their would have been more in game cinematics; They were too gorgeous. Since the story is told entirely in cenematics and images (no this is not an unironic statment nor is it a pun on the visual nature of video games). That being said, the story leaves enough breadcrumbs (or images of breadcrumbs) to have many different people draw many different conclusions and craft unique narratives. For me that makes this game EVEN more awesome hence my "?/10" for unlimited potential.Replayability: 7/10* This is not bad that I gave it a 7; I like that the game is feature light, I think its a strength in an atmospheric game. When measuring longevity, however, features go a LONG way in shaping that fact. Final verdict: 8.5/10 Would punish that A****le toad boss again.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is a game I'd been excited for for the past couple years now and I'm happy to say it does not disappoint. The visuals are some of the most beautiful I've seen in the pixel art genre, and there are various astonishing sights to see, some of which I would stop to study for a couple minutes. The soundtrack is great too, Disasterpeace does some of the most unique chiptune music I've ever heard.Before playing I was a little worried since a lot of people have been saying the game is too hard and frustrating to be fun, but after playing it through I wholeheartedly disagree. The bosses are very hard, that I wont deny anyone, but I found all of them really engaging and never frustrating, even though I died repeatedly on a few of them. Combat in this game is more about being aware of your surroundings and timing your actions than simply mashing buttons. I'm not against the idea of an easier difficulty setting for people who don't play this type of game often, but the experience of finally getting it down and sticking it to a boss is really satisfying. Some of the game's appeal would be lost without it.I finished the game in about 8 or 9 hours of play time, though I feel like there were a lot of secrets I missed, and there is a new game + mode as well so replay value seems good. Definitely will be playing this more in the future.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter does not hold your hand, it does not give you thorough tutorials, it does not explain what you're doing and why, and it does not go easy on you. This game may be a response to modern games that are overly expository but offer no challenge. This game is very challenging and offers no explanations. It lets you figure everything out on your own. And by God is it good. The game plays a little bit like a 2D Zelda game. You're given an top-down perspective and need to explore and battle your way through a mysterious world with your sword and other weapons you find along the way. Battles involve dashing, slashing, and shooting enemies. They're fast-paced and satisfying, relying almost entirely on skill. Like Zelda, it also has puzzles and a great deal of exploration. The world is large and mysterious. Secret areas and hidden items are scattered absolutely everywhere and it's fun and always worth it to explore and find them. The visual style is distinctive and striking, yet minimal, relying on neon pixel art. Very few bugs popped up during my playthrough, and the game is constantly receiving updates and fixes. The game isn't particularly long: It's only around 8 hours straight through for a decent player, but the sheer amount of collectibles and secrets make up for that.It's not a perfect game: the story might be too cryptic for its own good. After playing through the whole thing, I'm still not entirely sure what it's about. Its high level of difficulty can occasionally be frustrating, especially in the boss battles, which can be quite hard. This game is also the best argument for octo-gates on a controller I've seen: it's hard to line up dashes perfectly horizontally and vertically, but thankfully the game compensates for that a little.Overall it's a fantastic game. Many indie games on Steam try to bring back the challenge and style of 8 and 16-bit console games, but Hyper Light Drifter succeeds. It's not for everyone, but I would highly recommend it for those looking for an old-school challenge....I just intended to post a quick review to get that Steam badge. How did it get this long?!

												The game suggests that you get a controller.Get a god damned controller. The difficulty is already above average for games of this kind, mostly in a good way. The PC controls do precious little to help this.The cursor blends into the background, which is bad enough. What really throws it off is that the cursor's position also shifts as the camera moves. This means that through scene transitions, camera-shake with certain effects, and any cinematic movement with the camera will require you to manually track where the cursor has moved vs where you left it.The cursor determines where you are aiming and also what direction you dodge in. In a tight situation with alot of chaos on the screen, it is woefully easy to lose track of where you are pointing, which can lead to alot of pointless deaths. It also means that you cannot dodge in one direction while shooting in another, which is not a small limitation given what the challenge demands.Though, the theme and overall execution really carry this through. Especially if it's on sale, pick it up. Even if not, still worth the buy.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												Now, THIS is what Jotun should have been.  Hyper Light Drifter is largely a game about spectacle, but it is pretty bloody beautiful, fun, and somewhat poetic.Full disclosure, I did back this on Kickstarter and I am glad I did.  The graphical style is stunning and beautiful in it's more retro look and manages some amazing aesthetics and art design.  The game itself tells the story of the drifter entirely without dialogue and through short cut scenes and through your own actions.  While it can be a bit vague, it's definitely an experience and I enjoy that it feels like a complete story even if you don't have all the details.The design of everything is impressive and beautiful, with music that is equal parts ambient and haunting.  The problem comes with the controls.  While they aren't bad, they are a bit stiff and dashing out of combat takes some getting used to, as you can't dash through many attacks or enemies, like you might feel you can.  Swordplay lacks a bit of punch, but is otherwise satisfying.  Combat takes some getting used to.  I like this game, despite it's short length, however a problem bigger than the stiff controls is that not much is explained.  The keystones for opening doors?  The use of stone tablets?  Extra powers from different outfits?  You aren't told any of this through the game and even upgrades are a bit weird at first.  This let's the story be a bit poetic, but also makes the gameplay aspect of the game...a bit weak.Overall, it's a short experience with lots of beauty to behold, however unlike Jotun, there is a deep game that allows you to grow and improve, customize your character, and fight impressive bosses unlike much of what you have seen in other games.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												I have only been playing this game for a couple hours, and I'm absolutely entranced by the art style and design. The pixel art is absolutely beautiful and you honestly should buy it just for that. Furthermore, the soundtrack is very nice and relaxing and honestly is probably one of the best I've heard in any game. The gameplay is difficult. I've never played Dark Souls, but the way that I hear about Dark Souls sounds like my impression of the combat in this game: absolutely unforgiving. You have 5 health, that is all. Attacks do 1-2 points of damage depending on the enemy--though any that do two points of damage instead of just one tend to be pretty difficult to somehow get hit by. It's a lot of twitch reaction stuff, essentially watching every enemy around you trying to figure out what they might do next. Once they add enemies that have actual ranged attacks (aka they have a gun, too), the game becomes significantly more difficult. The save points are often but are sometimes quite brutal if you're having issues with a room, you clear it, and then die in the next part, it is very likely that you will have to redo the room you were struggling with since the game decides seemingly randomly sometimes when to save the game. I am barely even in the beginning of the game, and I can't imagine how much more interesting the game will become. I do find the non-verbal narrative charming, but can't help but wonder what is going on sometimes (compare to a particularly confusing panel of a manga with no text to help; sort of just staring trying to figure out what the pictures might mean). I'm sure that if something were really that confusing I could find an interpretation of the story online somewhere, but that would ruin the fun of the game. :)

												I got this game as a birthday gift. These are my FIRST IMPRESSIONS of playing the game a few minutes (I might update it when I finish the game).- The graphics are just lovely and the music is too.- At first it was very confusing for me to know where to go or what to do next but, since I'm a persistent person and wouldn't give up exploring and clicking everything, things started getting a bit more intuitive after a while.- I have attention deficit and the color scheme for this game doesn't seem to be helping. I get stuck a lot, not knowing which path to take and I can't quite realize where the map ends, thus ending up falling down and taking damage from it quite frequently. I guess my brain will need a bit more time to adjust, but that's me.- I really like the jump ability. Not only it allows you to jump a significant distance, but it is also quite useful to evade long range mob attacks during combat.- I quite like the combat system. Most pixel RPGs have a turn based combat system. That is not the case with this game. The character moves effortlessly in a very fluid way. It reminds me of a pixel version of an mmorpg combat system. I just love it.- I also like the "bullets" and the healing system. Make me feel like I have self sustain, even though I still die quite easily to the mobs xD- The way you go up and down the walls is also pretty cool. The teleport system across the map is nice too.- I just got to the first town and interacted with the NPCs in the shops. That was very confusing for me. The whole thing is images only and I'm used to text with dialogs and explanations. content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												Now, THIS is what Jotun should have been.  Hyper Light Drifter is largely a game about spectacle, but it is pretty bloody beautiful, fun, and somewhat poetic.Full disclosure, I did back this on Kickstarter and I am glad I did.  The graphical style is stunning and beautiful in it's more retro look and manages some amazing aesthetics and art design.  The game itself tells the story of the drifter entirely without dialogue and through short cut scenes and through your own actions.  While it can be a bit vague, it's definitely an experience and I enjoy that it feels like a complete story even if you don't have all the details.The design of everything is impressive and beautiful, with music that is equal parts ambient and haunting.  The problem comes with the controls.  While they aren't bad, they are a bit stiff and dashing out of combat takes some getting used to, as you can't dash through many attacks or enemies, like you might feel you can.  Swordplay lacks a bit of punch, but is otherwise satisfying.  Combat takes some getting used to.  I like this game, despite it's short length, however a problem bigger than the stiff controls is that not much is explained.  The keystones for opening doors?  The use of stone tablets?  Extra powers from different outfits?  You aren't told any of this through the game and even upgrades are a bit weird at first.  This let's the story be a bit poetic, but also makes the gameplay aspect of the game...a bit weak.Overall, it's a short experience with lots of beauty to behold, however unlike Jotun, there is a deep game that allows you to grow and improve, customize your character, and fight impressive bosses unlike much of what you have seen in other games.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Consider this an early impression rather than a full review of the game but I just wanted to share my opinions thus far.First off, HLD is absolutely gorgeous! It might be one of the best looking (2D) games I've seen in a very long time. The audio and music are also on point and fit the game very well. The combat is fast, fluid, fun and pretty hard but more on that later. I'd say the combat is a bit like Devil May Cry but in 2D.HLD isn't holding your hand either. It drops you straight into the action with basically no explaination whatsoever. This wouldn't be too bad if it weren't for the fact that they refuse to explain anything! I for example went to the Northern area first and there were some collectibles there, if I collect one of them a screen would appear with a square and one corner of the square would light up without any context. Maybe I haven't played far enough for it to make sense but as of now it's all a bit too criptic for my taste. Another problem I encountered are the PC controls. The game recommends a controller and I can see why! The mouse and keyboard controls aren't bad per se but in combat the cursor can become your worst enemy making combat way harder than it actually is. The problem is that both attacking and (more importantly) dodging go in the direction the cursor is facing. So say you're moving to the left but and you need to dodge an incoming attack but your cursor is on the right side of the screen you will dodge to the right even though you were moving to the left. It's infuriating and I hope there will be an update that prioritizes the direction you're going to the cursor. Yet even with these complaints I recommend Hyper Light Drifter just make sure you get yourself a controller and that you can handle the vagueness from time to time (although that might disappear later in the game). The combat still is a lot of fun and the atmosphere is just superb!

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												I really like the game : the atmosphere is quite unique,a lot of design are lovable and I found myself wanting to spare enemies until they ask for it, and there's a lot of love behind this game overall. My two main concern with it is that you cannot use the d-pad to play and you're forced to use the analog stick : I mind because the dash require precise direction and stupidly falling off cliffs could have been avoided (this among other things). And two the framerate is inconstant : again, the dash require precise tempo to be chained and it kind of ruin the experience when you're in the middle of tight battles (don't blame my pc, it runs modern-ish games on high, I don't think I'm at fault here)You play as an ex Interstellar 5555 member who wanted to join Attack on Titan only to realise Titans are already dead. Being the pinnacle of anime character, you have the ability  that every nekketsu protagonist dream to have : you cough blood.For one reason or another, you're going from place to place, doing genocide and regicide all while having acid trip and heart attacks.That's pretty much my understanding at least. HLD doesn't talk much to you, or just doesn't at all. Upgrades are immensely useful if you want to have a better experience, so think thrice about what upgrade you chose first : I heavily recommend that you get the attack that send back projectile, it help me a lot (but I'm not your mother you do what you want)All in all it's hard, but in a cheap way. Life bar could be restored at each death, it's not like it add challenge, it's just tedious.  but it's really enjoyable despite that. If you're getting crush by bosses : take a breath, observe them. deal with minions first and chain pistol + sword attack as much as possible. Also you can go in whichever direction you want, so if you're stuck with one boss, try another one, you might get useful weapons along to way to facilitate other encounters too.The game is fairly lenghty, expect 5 to 7 hours before finishing it. Aiming for 100% or doing the new game+ will take a lot more time as there's a lot to explore, even though sometime I just don't know how. I highly recomment this game, do not give up on it because the beginning is tedious : it's not that hard.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Easily one of the best games to come out this year, and the best game I've played this year. My jaw dropped when i saw the opening animation. Without anything approaching a word being uttered, just the sublime soundtrack and astounding pixel art, I felt more of a connection to the Drifter than to many other characters in books, films and videogames. And the game just kept delivering.For anyone that complains about the story being too vague, I feel that this simply isn't the case. HLD does a good job at world-building, and the little animations and 'text-boxes' that you see when interacting with NPCs highlight how the world is calm in the city-hub, but outside it there are all sorts of dangers. All the gameplay elements are on-point. Combat feels satisfying and rewarding, suitably Souls-esque with Zelda thrown in for good measure.Admittedly, I did get stuck at some points in the game, but a quick glance at a walkthrough will set you on the right path.All in all, Hyper Light Drifter is a thought-provoking, satisfying, mesmerising powerhouse of a game that I cannot recommend highly enough.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												I'm a backer, so take my opinion with a grain of salt, if you must.If you are a super busy person, here's the short of it.Reviewer quip: It's like if Shadow of the Colossus went through a pixelated, neon filter and came out on the other side as a Zelda game with an actual combat system.Pros:- Artwork is absolutely fantastic.- Story is conveyed with no dialog. Increases the myth of the world around you.- Combat is difficult, yet so satisfying once mastered.- Go into any area at your own will. Every area is accessible from the start.- Music adds a layer of atmosphere to each pixelated landscape.- UPDATE: 60 FPS makes this game's art and animation shine through.- UPDATE: Co-op mode is a neat little thing.Cons:- Locked at 30 FPS. No gameplay hindrance, but still significant IMO.- Controller issues at launch. (My PS4 controller works now, but do some research if not using a DS4)- The game is difficult. A few players probably won't finish the game because of this.- UPDATE: No online support for co-op.Pros:I backed this game several years ago, and it is beautiful to see this artwork come to life. The environments, the characters, the frames for the cutscenes are all fantastic. In my opinion, this is one of the best examples of pixel-art that I've seen in years. The closest thing I could compare it to is FEZ, both in style and quality. And that is some pretty high praise. The environments and the character designs do so much for this game. You get this sense of history from all of these gigantic shells scattered across (or a part of) the land. The narrative is told entirely without dialog. All relevant information is conveyed through stills, cutscenes, and the environments from before. I have not been this intrigued simply by the land and architecture of a video game since I played Shadow of the Colossus on the ol' PS2.I can see the combat in this game being divisive, but I believe it for the wrong reasons. YES, this game is DIFFICULT..... when you begin. I think, if you have played any game before with a rather unforgiving combat system (Dark Souls, Devil May Cry, etc...), you will get the hang of it by the time you beat the first boss (which you can do in any order!!). I was absolutely destroyed in EVERY encounter I got into when the game started. And, I'll admit, the thought went through my mind: "Am I bad at this game, or is the game simply unfair?" After a while, I learned to dodge more than I attack, prioritize certain enemies, and heal in appropriate situations. All of a sudden, the game clicked. My combat wasn't perfect, and I definitely still died a handful of times up to the end, but it is manageable if you give it a chance. And nothing beats that sense of accomplishment after clearing a room full of enemies and your characters slams his sword into the floor.The music is definitely good, the moody synths fit whichever environment you are in, but I can't say a single track "stood out." Then again, I don't think that's necessarily the point. The point of the music in this game is to simply add some atmosphere to wherever you are or whatever you are doing. It definitely succeeds in that area.Cons:The big debate at the moment seems to be with the developers' choice to lock the game at 30fps. Personally, I did look for the option to make that switch when I started playing, only to be surprised that there were only two options for the display: Windowed or Fullscreen. No option to change between 30, 60, or even higher FPS. I was slightly disappointed, because I feel like the artwork in this game would have flourished running at 60 FPS, but nonetheless, life goes on. Despite what you may read in other reviews, this does not make the game unplayable and you won't be throwing up out of your eyeballs because the option does not exist. I and plenty of other people have beaten the game at 30 FPS, and you should be able to as well. No longer an issue. Developer has updated the game to allow 60 FPS.Another issue I had was setting up a controller. The issue seems to be fixed now for PS4 controllers (I used a PS4 controller to play through this game in its entirety), but I cannot speak for the XBOX game pad.All in all, this is a solid game, one of my favorites I've played in a while. While I'm just one out of thousands, I feel great knowing that I helped these people achieve their goal and helped bring their project to life. That may affect my opinion of this, but I feel pretty confident that I would have my eye on this release, regardless of my backer status. The art is too good, the combat too sweet, and the world they have built is just so interesting.

Posted: April 7, 2016
												In lieu of a longer review, some quick combat tips:Healing takes time. Not a lot, but enough to get killed if you're careless.You can quick-fire your gun in the direction you're facing without aiming. This works better with some guns than others. Ranged enemies tend to fire a bit behind you, while melee enemies track your position more precisely.Make good use of save spots and health packs. Don't be afraid to repeat a room if you think you can do it better.The game has a lot of Metroid-like secret rooms. Hug walls and warp off the beaten path to get more upgrades. You can upgrade the sword to reflect projectiles. This is even better than it sounds.  Many find East the easiest way to start. Some of the rooms are pretty hard, but the boss is less difficult than the other three and you get the shotgun right after, which is a game-changer.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												With top down gameplay inspired by zelda with a dash of unforgiving fast paced combat, HLD was worth the price of admission. The music atmosphere and animations make enemies and the main character a pleasure to watch as they attempt to dismantle eachother. The game is also dense with secrets, with unfortunately some boiling down to running against walls and leaps of faith.I would wadger that a casual play through might clock in at 7-8 hours, depending on how many upgrades your willing to search high and low to finance. Almost all important additions to your abilities are bought from trainers, with the exception of guns that mostly lie behind the games major boss fights. Some are more useful then others: the chain dash is extremely important but upgrading your pistol clip or learning the slash into dash can wait.There are issues: frame rate can make executing some of your moves difficult. Your character will sometimes drop dashes when chaining them and there's not much to do, and it gets annoying trying to execute a 7+ chain dash required to clear some of the more difficult puzzels and your imput dropping or your character skidding to his certain death. The secrets in some areas are well marked, but those same markers in the same broad area might just be junk on the floor. It is compounded partially by the style of graphics: the charming pixels with tons of doo-dads on the walls and floor mean that it looks like everything might have a switch or passage behind it.You can't track where you've found things aside from the games diamond shards (which act as keys for progression) so you might wander an area for hours trying to find elusive secret collectables only to learn apon consulting a map that you've already cleaned it out long ago. Most of the rewards as you move to full collections tend to be minor: there are outfits that have different effects on them of varying use (some are quite subtle) but the most powerful effects they have are generally obtained past when they mattered anyway. That being said there's a lot of fun to be had exploring and buying upgrades and fighting some very intense ambushes and bosses in the grim but very colorful ruins of hyper light drifter.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												That feeling when beating some kid in a football minigame is more difficult than destroying the eldritch nightmares that haunt every second of your waking existence...Bloody hell the football minigame and the hyper-dash-challenge-thing are massive difficulty spikes. Whose idea was it to make you dash 800 times in a row? Sadistic. I got to six-hundred and something and buckled under the pressure and wrist strain. Why is the football kid such a prick? I'm supposed to be a hero or something, why do they want to hip-check me the second I get within a couple feet? Brutal.All right, that's all the salt out of me. This game may well be the first of any that I've seen on Steam, looked into a little, and then immediately bought without discussing it with friends. Haven't regretted that decision in the slightest (bar good-natured football kid hate). The game recommends you use a controller, but I recently switched over to using keyboard and mouse instead and I think I actually prefer it - if you want to use k&m, don't feel discouraged. Both options are definitely viable.Gameplay is fantastic; it has what I gather are Legend of Zelda and Souls Series vibes to it, with a few platformer elements thrown in. Exploration, combat and difficulty definitely seems reminiscent of the impression I got of Bloodborne, with the caveat that checkpoints for the most part seem a bit more frequent/forgiving.It can be a bit challenging to figure out what some things are supposed to do and what your objectives actually are, but considering the almost complete lack of text in the game it's probably pretty fantastic that a blind playthrough is even possible, which it very much is, even if the secrets are pretty easily missable. Luckily, most problems can be solved with the tried-and-tested "go wherever you haven't been yet and interact with whatever looks important" method.It's good. Well worth the £15. Would recommend.

												That feeling when beating some kid in a football minigame is more difficult than destroying the eldritch nightmares that haunt every second of your waking existence...Bloody hell the football minigame and the hyper-dash-challenge-thing are massive difficulty spikes. Whose idea was it to make you dash 800 times in a row? Sadistic. I got to six-hundred and something and buckled under the pressure and wrist strain. Why is the football kid such a prick? I'm supposed to be a hero or something, why do they want to hip-check me the second I get within a couple feet? Brutal.All right, that's all the salt out of me. This game may well be the first of any that I've seen on Steam, looked into a little, and then immediately bought without discussing it with friends. Haven't regretted that decision in the slightest (bar good-natured football kid hate). The game recommends you use a controller, but I recently switched over to using keyboard and mouse instead and I think I actually prefer it - if you want to use k&m, don't feel discouraged. Both options are definitely viable.Gameplay is fantastic; it has what I gather are Legend of Zelda and Souls Series vibes to it, with a few platformer elements thrown in. Exploration, combat and difficulty definitely seems reminiscent of the impression I got of Bloodborne, with the caveat that checkpoints for the most part seem a bit more frequent/forgiving.It can be a bit challenging to figure out what some things are supposed to do and what your objectives actually are, but considering the almost complete lack of text in the game it's probably pretty fantastic that a blind playthrough is even possible, which it very much is, even if the secrets are pretty easily missable. Luckily, most problems can be solved with the tried-and-tested "go wherever you haven't been yet and interact with whatever looks important" method.It's good. Well worth the £15. Would recommend.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												This game is absolutely incredible. The combination of a beautiful landscape, secret pathways hidden literally EVERYWHERE, and challenging bosses that sometimes border on absurd is a great mix. The "story" so to speak is very linear, and to be honest, hard to understand due to the lack of any actual text in game. But this doesn't detract from the game. If anything, it adds to it, because rather than being invested in certain characters and hoping for certain outcomes, it just becomes an endless battle for survival. This game requires good timing, you must learn the enemies attack patterns, and develop your own methods for dodging/ignoring them.That being said, I have one MAJOR complaint, and it relates to the final boss. One of the bosses attacks shoots out from the front of their face, and can literally one shot you if you are in the center of it. But that's not the issue. The issue with this attack is that if you are standing directly behind the boss, which is the ideal place (pretty much the ONLY place) to deal damage during this move, the attack can still hit you, ending what would have otherwise been a perfect attempt at it. Considering that during this attack is the only time you can deal 6 damage to the boss from melee range in one go, this seems like a large issue, as I have had many attempts where I got the boss below 6 health, only to die while standing completely on the opposite side of the boss when it attacks.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												I'm a backer, so take my opinion with a grain of salt, if you must.If you are a super busy person, here's the short of it.Reviewer quip: It's like if Shadow of the Colossus went through a pixelated, neon filter and came out on the other side as a Zelda game with an actual combat system.Pros:- Artwork is absolutely fantastic.- Story is conveyed with no dialog. Increases the myth of the world around you.- Combat is difficult, yet so satisfying once mastered.- Go into any area at your own will. Every area is accessible from the start.- Music adds a layer of atmosphere to each pixelated landscape.- UPDATE: 60 FPS makes this game's art and animation shine through.- UPDATE: Co-op mode is a neat little thing.Cons:- Locked at 30 FPS. No gameplay hindrance, but still significant IMO.- Controller issues at launch. (My PS4 controller works now, but do some research if not using a DS4)- The game is difficult. A few players probably won't finish the game because of this.- UPDATE: No online support for co-op.Pros:I backed this game several years ago, and it is beautiful to see this artwork come to life. The environments, the characters, the frames for the cutscenes are all fantastic. In my opinion, this is one of the best examples of pixel-art that I've seen in years. The closest thing I could compare it to is FEZ, both in style and quality. And that is some pretty high praise. The environments and the character designs do so much for this game. You get this sense of history from all of these gigantic shells scattered across (or a part of) the land. The narrative is told entirely without dialog. All relevant information is conveyed through stills, cutscenes, and the environments from before. I have not been this intrigued simply by the land and architecture of a video game since I played Shadow of the Colossus on the ol' PS2.I can see the combat in this game being divisive, but I believe it for the wrong reasons. YES, this game is DIFFICULT..... when you begin. I think, if you have played any game before with a rather unforgiving combat system (Dark Souls, Devil May Cry, etc...), you will get the hang of it by the time you beat the first boss (which you can do in any order!!). I was absolutely destroyed in EVERY encounter I got into when the game started. And, I'll admit, the thought went through my mind: "Am I bad at this game, or is the game simply unfair?" After a while, I learned to dodge more than I attack, prioritize certain enemies, and heal in appropriate situations. All of a sudden, the game clicked. My combat wasn't perfect, and I definitely still died a handful of times up to the end, but it is manageable if you give it a chance. And nothing beats that sense of accomplishment after clearing a room full of enemies and your characters slams his sword into the floor.The music is definitely good, the moody synths fit whichever environment you are in, but I can't say a single track "stood out." Then again, I don't think that's necessarily the point. The point of the music in this game is to simply add some atmosphere to wherever you are or whatever you are doing. It definitely succeeds in that area.Cons:The big debate at the moment seems to be with the developers' choice to lock the game at 30fps. Personally, I did look for the option to make that switch when I started playing, only to be surprised that there were only two options for the display: Windowed or Fullscreen. No option to change between 30, 60, or even higher FPS. I was slightly disappointed, because I feel like the artwork in this game would have flourished running at 60 FPS, but nonetheless, life goes on. Despite what you may read in other reviews, this does not make the game unplayable and you won't be throwing up out of your eyeballs because the option does not exist. I and plenty of other people have beaten the game at 30 FPS, and you should be able to as well. No longer an issue. Developer has updated the game to allow 60 FPS.Another issue I had was setting up a controller. The issue seems to be fixed now for PS4 controllers (I used a PS4 controller to play through this game in its entirety), but I cannot speak for the XBOX game pad.All in all, this is a solid game, one of my favorites I've played in a while. While I'm just one out of thousands, I feel great knowing that I helped these people achieve their goal and helped bring their project to life. That may affect my opinion of this, but I feel pretty confident that I would have my eye on this release, regardless of my backer status. The art is too good, the combat too sweet, and the world they have built is just so interesting.

												This is a beautiful game, both in its art and design.  Music and sound design is exceptional as well. Pros ------------- Only one difficulty level.  I like it when a game designer knows exactly how hard they want their game to be. No text in the game.  The story and "quest" are told through pictures. You can beat the game without upgrading or finding a single new piece of gear or new weapon.  They start you with everything you need and everything else you find is just a bonus. Cons ------------- Game is short.  I beat it in about 15 hours.  I spent a few hours in NG+ before moving on. There are really no "puzzles".  You pretty much just have to find keys to doors.  I was expecting, and would have appreciated some Zelda-esque puzzles. Final boss is a little too easy.Overall though, fantastic and absolutely worth the $20.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												TLDRGood -Art Style - Visuals are excellentUnique Setting - Alien WorldCombat - Could be Improved but SatisfiyingAc/Dc -Dialouge - There isn't any...so no Planescape Torment here you can take it or leave itSound - Effective EnoughDifficulty - Somewhat Tough - Pattern Learning Required to Beat BossesInstructions - MinimualBad -Exploration is really just a Pixel Hunt for the same two treasures screen after screenRepetitive and overlong at certain pointsLack of a concise storyMy Verdict?Very.....Okay. Reminds me of Axiom Verge and Zelda.Which is good in certain aspects such as excellent retro style art (not just pixel graphics) and it's adherence to theme throughout the expierence. The visuals are really a shining point for this game.However like Axiom Verge this title suffers from some retro game problems that have no place in modern games. I found the exploration portion of the game (it's a substantial part...like most of it) grew tedious as you pixel hunt each area trying to find extra loot hidden all over the level. The loot itself seems to be either health refills or coinage...and that's it. I mean if I'm searching for something and I stumble upon a seceret it would be nice to have some mystery as to what I was going to find there but some of you may enjoy getting the same christmas presents year after year. The combat style is sort of a mish-mash of button mashing and screen dashing that comes off okay. It could defintely be smoother but if you are technically precise and know what you are doing you will be successful. That's easier said than done as mob rushes are common and can be overwhelming.  The fact that you just start over at the begining of the screen is an old and tired mechnic that winds up having the effect of not caring one bit if I roll off a cliff or get KO'ed right before I kill the last bad man on screen.If your looking to scratch your Zelda itch and enjoy the aesthics of video games this a pretty solid title. I would say it needs some serious revamping to elevate itself up to Titan Souls or Shovel Knight territory.6/10 --- Solid Fun mixed with some tedious searching sets this as a slightly above average title in my book. While the price might be a bit too high for the gameplay itself the unique setting and visuals makes up for a bit.
